messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] mei translation
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Rich, Good question. I think the pronunciation would be bueju, but it sounds odd. I separated them out so you could see that it was the kanji for Bu meaning
messages.messageBody:
Hi Rich,



Good question. I think the pronunciation would be bueju, but it sounds odd.
I separated them out so you could see that it was the kanji for Bu meaning
Bishu and the kanji for E meaning Edo. I wonder if people of that period
seeing such an inscription would fill in the missing sounds. I will ask
about.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...]
Sent: Wednesday, December 03, 2003 11:07 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] mei translation



Thanks Gordon, so that would read Bue Ju or as you have Bu E Ju Kunimasa ?.
Short hand on mei, interesting concept.

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, December 03, 2003 9:46 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] mei translation


Hi Rich,



Rather than Bumu, I think Bu E ju or Bushu Edo ju using a shorthand. Date
is
correct.



Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...]
Sent: Wednesday, December 03, 2003 10:20 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] mei translation



all, I was tranlating this mei and nengo for someone on my board

http://www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/16.jpg

http://www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/15.jpg

I believe the mei reads Bumi Ju Kunimasa. I am unable to confirm the first
two characters but thought it referred to an Edo smith that also signed
Bushu Edo. The date I read as 8th month of the 6th year of Ansei 1854
so..August 1859.

thoughts ?

cheers

Rich
